message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The process described in the question is known as affinity maturation, which involves the selection and proliferation of B cells with higher affinity for specific antigens, leading to the production of antibodies with greater specificity and effectiveness in fighting off the pathogen in subsequent infections. Avidity refers to the strength of binding between an antibody and antigen, while immunoglobulin class switching involves the production of different classes of antibodies in response to different types of pathogens. T cell negative selection is a process of elimination of autoreactive T cells during their maturation in the thymus.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The process described in the question is affinity maturation, where B cells in the germinal center of lymphoid tissues will produce antibodies with greater specificity for an antigen in response to re-infection or exposure to the same pathogen. Avidity refers to the strength of binding between an antigen and antibody, immunoglobulin class switching refers to the ability of B cells to change antibody classes, and T cell negative selection refers to the elimination of self-reactive T cells during development.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on immunology for help. The process described is known as affinity maturation. During this process, B cells that produce antibodies with higher affinity for the specific antigen are preferentially selected, leading to an improved and more specific immune response upon re-infection. Avidity refers to the strength of binding between antibodies and antigens, while immunoglobulin class switching refers to the process by which B cells change the type of antibody they produce. T cell negative selection refers to the elimination of T cells with potential to cause autoimmune reactions.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The process described is affinity maturation, which is a process that allows B cells to produce antibodies with higher affinity and specificity for a given antigen. This process takes place in germinal centers of lymphoid tissues during the primary immune response, and upon re-exposure to the same antigen, a faster and more specific response is mounted due to the presence of memory B cells. Avidity refers to the strength of binding between an antigen and all the binding sites on an antibody molecule, while immunoglobulin class switching and T cell negative selection are different processes in the immune system.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The process described in the scenario is affinity maturation, where the B cells in the germinal center undergo mutations in their immunoglobulin genes, leading to the production of antibodies with higher affinity for the antigen. Avidity refers to the strength of binding between an antibody and its antigen, while immunoglobulin class switching involves the switching of antibody isotypes to optimize the immune response. T cell negative selection is the process by which autoreactive T cells are eliminated during development in the thymus.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The process described is affinity maturation, which is the process by which B cells undergo somatic hypermutation in the germinal center, resulting in the production of antibodies with greater affinity for the pathogen. This allows for a more efficient and specific response upon re-infection. Avidity refers to the strength of the interaction between an antigen and its antibody. Immunoglobulin class switching is the process by which B cells switch the type of immunoglobulin they produce, and T cell negative selection is the process by which T cells that recognize self-antigens are eliminated.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The process described in the question is called affinity maturation. During affinity maturation, B cells undergo somatic hypermutation, leading to the generation of B cells with higher affinity for the pathogenic antigen. This results in a stronger and more specific immune response upon subsequent infection with the same pathogen. Avidity refers to the strength of binding between an antibody and its antigen, while immunoglobulin class switching refers to the process of changing the class of antibodies produced by B cells. T cell negative selection is the process by which developing T cells in the thymus are eliminated if they are too strongly reactive against self-antigens.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on immunology for help. The process described in the question is affinity maturation, where B cells in the germinal center undergo somatic hypermutation and selection to produce antibodies with higher affinity for the antigen. Avidity refers to the binding strength between an antibody and multiple antigenic determinants. Immunoglobulin class switching is the process of changing the class of antibody produced by the B cell. T cell negative selection is the process of eliminating self-reactive T cells to prevent autoimmunity.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The process described is affinity maturation, which occurs in the germinal center of lymphoid tissues as the B cells undergo somatic hypermutation and selection to produce antibodies with higher affinity for the pathogen's antigens. Avidity refers to the strength of binding between antibodies and antigens, while immunoglobulin class switching involves the production of different classes of antibodies (e.g. IgM to IgG). T cell negative selection is a process by which autoreactive T cells are eliminated during development in the thymus.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on immunology for help. The process described is affinity maturation, which is a process that occurs in the germinal center of the lymphoid tissues where B cells undergo somatic hypermutation, leading to the production of B cells with higher affinity to the pathogen. This allows for a more effective and specific immune response upon re-infection with the same pathogen. Avidity refers to the overall strength of binding between an antibody and antigen, while immunoglobulin class switching refers to the process by which B cells change from producing one class of antibody to another. T cell negative selection is a process of eliminating autoreactive T cells in the thymus.
